data.title: Champions League last-16 draw in full, dates, and who Arsenal and Man City play
data.meta_description: Holders Manchester City are favourites to win the whole thing again, but Arsenal are in the mix given their strong start to the season
data.text:
Arsenal will take on Porto for a place in the Champions League quarter-finals, with holders Manchester City drawn against FC Copenhagen in the round of 16.

Arsenal and City topped their respective groups, and both sides will arguably be pleased with their draws given Paris Saint-Germain were among the potential opponents, likewise Serie A champions Napoli.

And it is Napoli who arguably have the standout tie of the round against Barcelona, who are currently off the pace in La Liga.

PSG, meanwhile, face Spanish side Real Sociedad, who topped their group ahead of Inter Milan.

Champions League last-16 fixtures

FC Porto vs Arsenal

Napoli vs Barcelona

Paris Saint-Germain vs Real Sociedad

Inter Milan vs Atletico Madrid

PSV Eindhoven vs Borussia Dortmund

Lazio vs Bayern Munich

FC Copenhagen vs Manchester City

RB Leipzig vs Real Madrid

Champions League last-16 dates

The first legs will be played across 13-14 and 20-21 February, with the return legs then on 5-6 and 12-13 March.

Holders City get easiest tie – on paper

Among the group runners-up were the fourth, sixth and seventh best teams in Europe – PSG, Inter and Leipzig based on Uefa’s club coefficients – and so naturally City landed on the team ranked 37th, the lowest of the eight.

Those who feel City have the luck of the draw will have certainly scoffed, but Pep Guardiola would be wise not to overly underestimate Copenhagen, the side that beat Manchester United 4-3 at home in November.

The Danish side were also unlucky to leave Old Trafford without a point in October, and while City are a different beast to their city rivals, their current form could offer Copenhagen some hope.

Copenhagen managed to hold City to a 0-0 draw at home in the group stages last season.

That’s the positive. The mighty negative was the 5-0 defeat in the reverse fixture, when Erling Haaland score twice in the first half to get the City machine rolling.

Arsenal and their fans expect

Premier League leaders Arsenal are fourth favourites to win the Champions League this season – behind City, Bayern and Real Madrid – a sign of the times despite having not played in the competition since 2016-17.

In Mikel Arteta they very much trust, and in Porto they face a side currently in a three-way title race with Benfica and Sporting in the Primeira Liga.

Porto in fact head to Sporting on Monday night, and in their Champions League group, the 2004 winners overcame both Antwerp and Shakhtar Donetsk twice, but lost both of their matches to Barcelona.

Arsenal will be expected to reach the last eight, therefore, and it will be the first time for 14 years they have faced Porto in the Champions League.

On that occasion, in the 2009-10 round of 16, Arsenal lost the first leg 2-1 away, but made amends with a 5-0 demolition at home – thanks, of course, to a Nicklas Bendtner hat-trick.
